title: How do viruses jump from animals to humans? - Ben Longdon

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern of the Maryland Department of Health regarding the prize pigs at the country fair?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: They have specific interactions with their host species.

options.label: B
options.text: They have proteins adapted to bind with matching receptors on human respiratory cells.

options.label: C
options.text: They have enzymes that break down the host cell's DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a mechanism to suppress the host's immune system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of a virus encountering a new species and attempting to infect it?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of virologists in preventing epidemics caused by viruses?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They develop vaccines and containment protocols to stop the spread of viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: They monitor populations to quickly identify new outbreaks.

title: The secret language of trees - Camille Defrenne and Suzanne Simard

multiple-choice.question: What is the secret to the success of the oldest trees in the forest?

options.text: They have the largest mycorrhizal networks with the most connections to other trees.

options.label: B
options.text: They have the strongest root systems that can absorb nutrients from the soil.

options.label: C
options.text: They have the ability to photosynthesize sugars at a faster rate.

options.label: D
options.text: They have the largest leaves that can absorb sunlight.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of mycorrhizal fungi in the forest ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They break down organic matter and release nutrients into the soil.

options.label: B
options.text: They form symbiotic relationships with tree roots and facilitate the exchange of nutrients and signaling molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: They produce sugars through photosynthesis and provide fuel for trees.

options.label: D
options.text: They compete with trees for resources and nutrients.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Through a process of active transport and endocytosis.

options.label: B
options.text: They can produce sugars through photosynthesis and provide fuel for trees.

options.label: C
options.text: They can compete with trees for resources and nutrients.

options.label: D
options.text: They can form symbiotic relationships with other fungi and facilitate the exchange of nutrients and signaling molecules.

options.label: B
options.text: They share information about the availability of nutrients and resources.

options.label: C
options.text: They share information about the presence of predators or competitors.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not communicate with each other through their fungal networks.

options.label: B
options.text: They facilitate the exchange of nutrients and signaling molecules between trees.

options.label: C
options.text: They break down organic matter and release nutrients into the soil.

options.label: D
options.text: They produce sugars through photosynthesis and provide fuel for trees.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of fungi in passing information between trees?

options.label: B
options.text: They can pass information about the presence of predators or competitors.

options.label: C
options.text: They can pass information about events like drought or insect attacks.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not pass information between trees.

options.label: A
options.text: They can absorb nutrients from the soil more efficiently than fungi.

options.label: B
options.text: They can produce sugars through photosynthesis and provide fuel for fungi.

options.label: C
options.text: They can form symbiotic relationships with other trees and facilitate the exchange of nutrients and signaling molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not benefit from being part of a mycorrhizal network.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: They do not tell when nutrients or signaling molecules are coming from a member of their own species or not.

title: The lovable (and lethal) sea lion - Claire Simeone

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the hunting behavior of sea lions?

options.text: They hunt alone and prefer shallow waters.

options.label: B
options.text: They hunt in groups and prefer deep waters.

options.text: They hunt only at night and prefer to stay on land.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.text: They have a long memory and can remember things for a long time.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: They are not affected by the changing ocean conditions.

options.label: C
options.text: They are vulnerable to toxic algae species that thrive in the warmer oceans.
